chapter.title: Results and Comparisson with Fortan Source Code

section.title: Note on compiling the original code
section.para: On the following, we are going to use the gfortran compiler; gfortran is a freely redistributable fortran compiler. It is part of GCC, the GNU compiler suite, and is currently part of that distribution. gfortran comes with most Unix - type OSs.

To compile a program, say TEST.F, the basic syntax is:
bash$ gfortran TEST.F -o test.e
which should result in the creation of a (executable) file named test.e.
section.note: Our knowledge of FORTRAN and gfortran is very limited, so this chapter should only be seen as a harsh guideline

section.para: The FUNDARG.F and fundarg.cpp produce exactly the same results. Note however that, when running the FUNDARG.F routine, all input/output parameters MUST be provided in explicit double precision format (i.e. ending with D0 or something similar). E.g., for the test case provided at header, declare epoch as T = 0.07995893223819302D0 and NOT T = 0.07995893223819302 Same is true for comparing the results, i.e. WRITE(*,100) 'dl = ',DABS(2.291187512612069099D0-L)

For example, the test case provided in the fundarg.cpp header, could be setup as a FORTRAN routine in the following way:
Verifiyng FUNDARG.F test case
PROGRAM MAIN DOUBLE PRECISION T, L, LP, F, D, OM T = 0.07995893223819302D0 CALL FUNDARG ( T, L, LP, F, D, OM ) WRITE(*,100) 'dl = ',DABS(2.291187512612069099D0-L) WRITE(*,100) 'dlp = ',DABS(6.212931111003726414D0-LP) WRITE(*,100) 'df = ',DABS(3.658025792050572989D0-F) WRITE(*,100) 'dd = ',DABS(4.554139562402433228D0-D) WRITE(*,100) 'dom = ',DABS(-0.5167379217231804489D0-OM) 100 FORMAT(A,F20.15) END
This block, could be added at the top of the file FUNDARG.F to run the test case. The code could then be compiled, using e.g.:
bash$ gfortran FUNDARG.F -o fundarg.e
And running the executable (i.e. fundarg.e) should produce something like the following:
dl = 0.000000000000076 dlp = 0.000000000009700 df = 0.000000000000078 dd = 0.000000000009591 dom = 0.000000000000000

The PMSDNUT2.F and mpsdnut2.cpp functions, do not produce identical results. That is because FORTRAN seems to produce small 'garbage' when transforming elements of the vectors XS(25), XC(25), YS(25), YC(25). To fix this, use an explicit double decleration at the source code, i.e. instead of
DATA .( (IARG(I,J),i=1,6), PER(J), XS(J), XC(J), YS(J), YC(J), . J=16,25) ./ 1, -1, 0, -2, 0, -1, 1.1196992, -0.4, 0.3, -0.3, -0.4, . 1, -1, 0, -2, 0, -2, 1.1195149, -2.3, 1.3, -1.3, -2.3,
use:
.( (IARG(I,J),i=1,6), PER(J), XS(J), XC(J), YS(J), YC(J), . J=16,25) ./ 1, -1, 0, -2, 0, -1, 1.1196992, -0.4D0, 0.3D0, -0.3D0, -0.4D0, . 1, -1, 0, -2, 0, -2, 1.1195149, -2.3D0, 1.3D0, -1.3D0, -2.3D0,
Note that c++ normally does not need this, but in any case the corresponding elements are declared in scientific notation.

section.title: Testing the FORTRAN Implementation
section.para:
You can easily verify/test the original FORTRAN code, using the utilities provided within the package. To do this, you will need the FORTRAN source code, which can either be downloaded from the corresponding IERS website, or use the already downloaded subroutines existing in the folder test/fortran. Either way, you will need to have the following files (in the test/fortran folder):
ARG2.F CNMTX.F FCNNUT.F FUNDARG.F MCNMTX.F ORTHO_EOP.F PMSDNUT2.F RG_ZONT2.F UTLIBR.F
Follow the steps described below, to create a program testing the results of FORTRAN subroutines.

procedure.title: Test FORTRAN
procedure.para: To create a test program for FORTRAN.

step.para: Make sure you have all the required FORTRAN files in the test/fortran folder (see ). In addition, the files compile.sh and test.f should also reside in the same folder (these files come with the package).

Compile the FORTRAN subroutines and the test.f program, using compile.sh. To do this, you only need to execute the script:bash$ chmod +x compile.sh; ./compile.sh The latter is a dead simple bash script, with a list of command for compiling the subroutines and linking to create the test program. Compilation flags are not used, so if you do know what you 're doing, you can edit this file. The compile.sh script uses gfortran to compile the FORTRAN subroutines. If you don't have this program either install it, or edit the file to use a different compiler.

If the previous step ended successefuly, you must have a file named test.e in the test/fortran folder. Go ahead and run this program. bash$ ./test.e It should report a list of results from running the test cases for every subroutine. The report should be self-explanatory. You can also save the output in a file for further use (see). bash$ ./test.e > fortran.test
